response.answer_text: The short answer is that not all American states have straight borders. This is the map of the Savannah River that divides South Carolina and Georgia:  Rivers are commonly used as state boundaries in the US. The United States is a fairly new country compared to places like Europe. Several states, particularly in the West, were defined by geographic coordinates rather than by the people who lived there over the centuries; those tend to be straight. Here is the “Four Corners” region of Utah, Colorado, Arizona and New Mexico:  So, the state boundaries in the US are straight lines, except when they aren’t.
